data: Engineer Spotlight The Board of Licensure would like to shine a spotlight on some of the talented engineers licensed to practice in the State of Mississippi . Licensees featured on this page are selected randomly. December 2025 Engineer Spotlight: Christian Jon Louis Duncan, PE The Mississippi Board of Licensure for Professional Engineers and Surveyors would like to shine a spotlight on Professional Engineer Christian Jon Louis Duncan. Mr. Duncan is a graduate of the Bagley College of Engineering at Mississippi State University where he received the following degrees: Bachelor of Science degree in Mechanical Engineering Master of Science degree in Civil Engineering Currently he is working on a PhD in Mechanical Engineering which he anticipates will be completed in Spring 2026. He is currently licensed in Mississippi, Alabama, Arkansas, Tennessee and Kansas. Learn more about Mr. Duncan and find out why professional licensure is important to him in the comments below: 1. W hy did you choose engineering or surveying? " I chose to become an engineer to solve problems. I have always wanted to understand how things work on a fundamental level to solve more complicated problems. My parents always encouraged me to become an engineer. " 2. How long have you been licensed in the State of Mississippi and do you also hold other state licenses? " I earned my Professional Engineer (PE) license in Mississippi as an initial licensee in January 2021." 3. What advice would you give to your younger self (HS grad, college grad, etc)? " Try to think outside of the box and stay motivated. Set a goal to learn something new every day. It’s easy to get bogged down with difficult coursework but remember to be thankful for the opportunity to learn, and don’t be afraid to ask questions. " 4. What is your favorite quote? " “ All models are wrong, but some are useful. ” – George E. P. Box 5. Tell us about a recent project you worked on that exemplifies why you love being an engineer. " In 2023, I designed a hybrid high-strength steel plate girder in Mississippi. The project included many different design considerations and challenges, including seismic design, and pushed me to learn new design approaches. It was challenging but extremely rewarding. " 6. Why is professional licensure important to you? " A professional engineering license sets the highest standard that an engineer can strive for. Obtaining a professional engineering license is not just personal achievement, but it is also a reminder of an engineer’s responsibility to the public. " October 2025 Engineer Spotlight: David Judice, PE The Mississippi Board of Licensure for Professional Engineers and Surveyors would like to shine a spotlight on Professional Engineer David Judice. Mr. Judice is a graduate of the University of Louisiana at Lafayette (home of the Ragin' Cajuns) where he received a Bachelor of Science degree in Civil Engineering. Mr. Judice currently works with Waggoner Engineering, where he serves as a Senior Project Manager. Mr. Judice is currently licensed in six states: Alabama Florida Louisiana Mississippi Tennessee Texas Learn more about Mr. Judice and find out why professional licensure is important to him in the comments below: 1. W hy did you choose engineering or surveying? "From a young age, I developed a strong interest in building infrastructure, inspired by my father and brother, who worked as engineering technicians in the field of electrical engineering. During college, I spent my summers working as a roustabout, where I gained hands-on experience rebuilding offshore oil platforms. That experience not only strengthened my technical skills but also solidified my desire to pursue a career in engineering." 2. How long have you been licensed in the State of Mississippi and do you also hold other state licenses? " I earned my Professional Engineer (PE) license in Mississippi as of October 2024. I am also licensed as a PE in Texas, Louisiana, Alabama, Tennessee and Florida." 3. What advice would you give to your younger self (HS grad, college grad, etc)? " I would encourage my younger self to keep an open mind about career paths and to pursue internships or entry-level jobs in various fields to help clarify what interests and drives them. As we grow, our interests may change, and that’s perfectly fine. Finding your passion and following it will set you on a path of personal and professional fulfillment. " 4. What would you say to young people, who might be interested in STEM careers such as engineering and / or surveying? "For those considering a career in engineering or surveying, keep an open mind and absorb as much as possible during undergraduate studies. Engage with your peers and ask questions—they can help guide you toward a specialization that best aligns with your strengths and interests. The engineering field is expansive and evolving, and with so much opportunity on the horizon, it's an exciting time to enter this field." 5. Tell us about a recent project you worked on that exemplifies why you love being an engineer. "Currently, I’m serving as a Senior Project Manager with Waggoner Engineering, overseeing diverse assignments that range from transportation and traffic engineering to water and wastewater projects, as well as grant management. This role requires me to guide projects from their initial concept through to construction services. The breadth of responsibility, coupled with the positive impact these projects have on communities, reminds me daily of why I’m passionate about my profession." 6. Why is professional licensure important to you? "Professional licensure signifies a commitment to excellence and accountability. As an engineer, signing and sealing plans places a significant responsibility on me as the engineer of record, and I approach this responsibility with the utmost seriousness. Producing quality, enduring work that serves the public instills a sense of pride and fulfillment, knowing I’ve contributed positively to our communities and helped lay the groundwork for future generations." August 2025 Engineer Spotlight: William Brian Fulton, PE The Mississippi Board of Licensure for Professional Engineers and Surveyors would like to shine a spotlight on Professional Engineer William Brian Fulton. Mr. Fulton is a graduate of Mississippi State University where he received both a Bachelor of Science and Master of Science degree in Civil Engineering. He was also a participant in the Cooperative (Co-op) Education Program at Mississippi State University and has firsthand knowledge of the benefit of the program on so many professionals. Mr. Fulton currently serves as the County Administrator for Jackson County, Mississippi. Learn more about Mr. Fulton and find out why professional licensure is important to him in the comments below: 1. W hy did you choose engineering or surveying? "I chose a degree in Civil Engineering primarily because I excelled in mathematics, and I enjoyed being around the construction industry." 2. How long have you been licensed in the State of Mississippi and do you also hold other state licenses? " I have been licensed in Mississippi for more than 20 years, and I also hold a PE license in the State of Alabama." 3. What advice would you give to your younger self (HS grad, college grad, etc)? "The advice I would give my younger self would be to learn good study habits because you definitely need them to be able to get through engineering school, and to explore the variety of career opportunities that are out there for engineers." 4. What would you say to young people, who might be interested in STEM careers such as engineering and / or surveying? "Careers in STEM are here to stay. I don’t think you can go wrong with getting a degree in engineering or surveying." 5. Why is professional licensure important to you? "Professional licensure is important because it sets you apart from other engineers that are not licensed. It has a level of prestige, but it also comes with a higher level of accountability, ethical standards, and commitment. I would recommend all engineers and surveyors to seek licensure." July 2025 Engineer Spotlight: Isaac Howard, Ph.D., P.E., F. ASCE The Mississippi Board of Licensure for Professional Engineers and Surveyors would like to shine a spotlight on Professional Engineer Isaac Howard. We have never been more excited and quite frankly more proud than we are right now to shine a spotlight on a dedicated #professionalengineer in the State of Mississippi than we are right now. Dr. Howard is the Director of the Richard A. Rula School of Civil & Environmental Engineering in the Bagley College of Engineering at #MississippiStateUniversity. And we are excited, because of the impact he has on so many #engineeringmajors coming through our state. Just recently, we were discussing in our office how to increase the number of #engineeringmajors who take the #FundamentalsofEngineering (FE) exam, who pursue #EngineerIntern enrollment and ultimately who become #ProfessionalEngineers. Conclusion.....it begins with instructors and professionals like Mr. Howard who are sharing with students the importance of these milestones in both their professional careers and personal lives. We also, like the non traditional spelling of "Isaac". Dr. Howard holds the following degrees: Degree University Year Area BSE Arkansas State University 2001 Civil Engineering MSCE West Virginia University 2002 Civil Engineering PhD University of Arkansas 2006 Civil Engineering Learn more about Dr. Howard and why professional licensure is important to him below: Q1. Why did you choose engineering? " I grew up in a farming community in eastern Arkansas. I was accustomed to heavy equipment, soil, working outside, and I also liked math and science, so Civil Engineering was a good fit for me. " Q2. How long have you been licensed in the State of Mississippi and do you also hold other state licenses? Dr. Howard has been a licensed #ProfessionalEngineer in the State of Mississippi since January 2013 and currently is licensed just in the Sip. Q 3. What is your favorite quote? I have several quotes that I like – hard to pick just one. For this, I picked: " Success is the sum of small efforts repeated day in and day out. " -- Robert Collier, American writer Q4. Tell us about a recent project you worked on that exemplifies why you love being an engineer and / surveyor? " I have been working for over ten years on ways to measure how durable different blends of asphalt are over years in service. Understanding how to make asphalt more durable impacts our ability to recycle other materials into asphalt, it affects economics of highway and airfield networks, and it affects ride quality, safety, and overall highway functionality. In 2022, the work we have done (myself and those listed below) was adopted as AASHTO T 401-22: Standard Method of Test for Cantabro Abrasion Loss of Asphalt Mixture Specimens. Rabeea W. Bazuhair, Ben C. Cox, Jesse D. Doyle, Jonathan Easterling, Jessica V. Lewis, Alex Middleton, Carl Pittman, Braden T. Smith, Abhinash Subedi, W. Griffin Sullivan. " Q5. Why is professional licensure important to you? " Professional licensure helps protect the health, safety, and welfare of the public. Professional licensure is also a lifelong process through which licensed professionals continue to stay current in their field. Licensure is one of several ways that engineers and surveyors can better themselves and in turn improve people’s lives. " June 2025 Engineer Spotlight: Kayla Erickson, PE The Mississippi Board of Licensure for Professional Engineers and Surveyors would like to shine a spotlight on Professional Engineer Kayla Erickson. Kayla is a graduate of Montana State University (another MSU) where she received a Bachelor of Science degree in chemical engineering. Like many who are drawn to the profession, Kayla was introduced to STEM by a family member. Her father worked in the chemical engineering field. We were also very impressed with Kayla's responses to the spotlight survey. In particular, the following quote: “Get up, dress up, show up” Great advice to her younger self ........ and well to all of us, in general. By show up, we think she means be engaged in whatever it is you are doing. Learn more about Kayla and why professional licensure is important to her below: Q1. Why did you choose engineering? " Chemical engineering runs in my blood. My father recently retired from his career in chemical engineering, and I grew up flipping through his textbooks, accompanying him onsite with clients and in the lab, and listening to him solve technical problems over the phone on long drives to site. My father encouraged me to pursue a STEM career and constantly challenge myself to sharpen my technical skills. " Q2. How long have you been licensed in the State of Mississippi and do you also hold other state licenses? " I’ve been a licensed professional engineer since June of 2021. My Southern Region work has increased this year, which led me to get licensed in Mississippi during Fall 2024. I currently hold PE licenses in WA, PA, DE, NJ, MS, and AR. " Q 3. What advice would you give to your younger self (HS grad, college grad, etc.)? " Dear Younger Self, Networking matters, do it. The engineering career fair and the on-campus FE Exam are the best stops you will make on campus. The most impactful advice you’ll receive in college comes from Dr. Hayes, “Learn how to read an error message”. The most useful life advice you’ll follow is, “Get up, dress up, show up”. When you make it, turn around and help the next one in line. Sincerely, Mid-Career Self " Q4. What would you say to young people, who might be interested in STEM careers such as engineering or surveying? " If you are interested in a STEM career, maybe engineering, go for it. Ensure your grasp of lower-level math is strong, even if it takes you longer to get to the higher levels with that strong foundation. Network in school and in your career. Many universities have Engineering days or summer camps for high school age students to gain exposure. Be willing to say “yes” to every relevant opportunity that comes your way at the beginning of your career and seek out field experience right out of the gate. Don’t get discouraged if your course work is hard- you are quite literally going to school to be a professional problem solver. " Q5. Tell us about a recent project you worked on that exemplifies why you love being an engineer and / surveyor? " Recently, I’ve been heading up a project which was originally scoped as TSS removal from wastewater, though through a site visit and data analysis, we determined the root cause is not wastewater TSS but instead, a chemical dosing problem. This project exemplifies why I love being an engineer because on this project I’ve gotten to share my wastewater expertise, travel to a new state, work with a great client team, and help identify the actual problem, develop a solution, and save the client money. It is exciting when my work leads to value added and new understanding, rather than just providing an off the shelf solution. " Q6. Why is professional licensure important to you? " Professional licensure is important to me because it is a foundation for my career, provides networking and growth opportunities, and ensures that I continue my education in engineering annually. " May 2025 Engineer Spotlight: Alex Ray Price, PE The Mississippi Board of Licensure for Professional Engineers and Surveyors would like to shine a spotlight on newly licensed Professional Engineer Alex Price. Alex has a very diverse educational background in that he has an affiliation with several Mississippi schools including: Pearl River Community College William Carey University East Mississippi Community College and ultimately, Mississippi State University where he received his Bachelor of Science degree in Civil Engineering. Just recently, he received a Masters degree in Business Administration from Louisiana State University. The last degree has us wondering how he sleeps when State and LSU play each other in football. Inquiring minds want to know Alex? We also applaud Alex's support of the Co-op experience. Did you know that we give six months of work experience credit for Co-op? So not only do you gain valuable work experience, that experience counts when you apply for your PE licensure in Mississippi. Lastly, we very much appreciates the pride Alex has in his engineering and educational accomplishments as indicated by the diplomas and licensure certificate on display in his office. We get you Alex and we salute your accomplishments. Keep rising. Learn more about Alex and why professional licensure is important to him below: Q1. Why did you choose engineering? "I chose engineering because it is a gratifying field to work in. At my current job, we are able to serve and positively impact the lives of thousands of Mississippians. Also, being able to see projects that you designed come to life in the field is very rewarding." Q2. How long have you been licensed in the State of Mississippi and do you also hold other state licenses? " I have been licensed as a Professional Engineer in Mississippi since March of 2024. " Q 3. What advice would you give to your younger self (HS grad, college grad, etc.)? "The best advice I could give is to commit fully to your program of study and to utilize the Co-Op program at your university to gain professional work experience prior to graduation." Q4. What would you say to young people, who might be interested in STEM careers such as engineering or surveying? "I would say if you have any interest whatsoever to pursue it. Engineering and surveying are both very rewarding career fields that involve complex problem-solving skills. Your day-to-day is rarely ever the same, and I enjoy that about the profession." Q5. Tell us about a recent project you worked on that exemplifies why you love being an engineer and / surveyor? "One recent project we completed involved the construction of a new substation near Purvis, MS. The project encompassed various aspects of design and construction, engaging multiple engineering disciplines, including environmental, structural, and electrical engineering. Managing and overseeing the project from conception to energization was highly rewarding, providing a profound sense of accomplishment upon its completion." Q6. Why is professional licensure important to you? "I think professional licensure is important because with that licensure comes a new level of responsibility. It requires you as an engineer to hold your work at the highest standard to protect the public. " April 2025 Engineer Spotlight : Mariette Wientjes, PE The Mississippi Board of Licensure for Professional Engineers and Surveyors would like to shine a spotlight on recently licensed Professional Engineer Mariette Wientjes. Mariette is a graduate of Mississippi State University (MSU) where she received a Bachelor of Science degree in civil engineering. We are both encouraged and inspired by Mariette. We recently had the opportunity to observe her passion and commitment to giving back to the profession in both her involvement and dedication to two events: The first being the Mississippi Engineering Society winter meeting and second the ASCE Gulf Coast student symposium held on the MSU campus in March 2025. She has a energy and enthusiasm that cannot be denied. We can very much appreciate that as we hope to draw more young people into the #engineering and #surveying professions. Like many who are drawn to the profession, it was the efforts of a teacher who introduced Mariette to #engineering. Now she in turn is giving back in many ways to help draw and retain others in the profession. Learn more about Mariette and why professional licensure is important to her below: Q1. Why did you choose engineering? " My high school geometry teacher advised a STEM club and I really enjoyed the creativity of the challenges I took part in through that. She always used to ask on the first day of class, “How do you touch the ceiling?” and I like to think that engineering follows that similar concept; the end goal is clear, but there are a lot of different ways to get to that goal. As for Civil Engineering specifically, I ended up stumbling my way into the field as a happy accident. In high school, I was interviewed for my involvement in the STEM club and when asked about what type of engineering I wanted to pursue, I panicked and said “Civil”, with no actual idea as to what a civil engineer does. Fast forward a year later, I had to do a research paper on a career so it gave me a chance to learn about the field and ultimately helped me decide that that was what I wanted to study. " Q2. How long have you been licensed in the State of Mississippi and do you also hold other state licenses? " I received my license in Mississippi in July 2024. " Q 3. What advice would you give to your younger self (HS grad, college grad, etc.)? " Just keep going, and work on your time management skills. It might take a little longer than expected, but earning your degree, passing the exams, and getting your license will all be worth it in the end. " Q4. What would you say to young people, who might be interested in STEM careers such as engineering or surveying? " If this is a field you want to pursue, something that brings you joy, keep persevering. Grades are important, but they are not the be-all and end-all that determines if you will be a good engineer. Your education is an important stepping stone to better your engineering judgement. " Q5. Tell us about a recent project you worked on that exemplifies why you love being an engineer and / surveyor? " I’ve had the honor to work on a safety project concerning some dangerous intersections near where I am from. This has helped me to learn about new intersection designs, improve my CADD skills, and be involved in the plan-design process. Beyond that, knowing that I am contributing to making our state roads safer for people like my parents that drive through these particular intersections every day means the world to me. " Q6. Why is professional licensure important to you? " I believe professional licensure is a summation of the work put in to developing yourself in this field. It shows a strong work ethic and integrity, and keeps you focused on the most important thing, which is the health, safety, and welfare of the public. " March 2025 Engineer Spotlight: Herbert "Bert" Eugene Moore, PE The Mississippi Board of Licensure for Professional Engineers and Surveyors would like to shine a spotlight on licensed Professional Engineer Herbert Eugene Moore (or Bert as he prefers to be called). Bert Moore is a 1999 graduate of Louisiana State University where he received a Bachelor of Science degree in Civil Engineering with a minor in Land Survey. Bert worked as a traffic engineering consultant in private industry for over 10 years before leaving to become the District 61 Traffic Operations Engineer for LADOTD and then joining Gresham Smith in 2014. Bert is a licensed Professional Engineer, Professional Land Surveyor and a Professional Traffic Operations Engineer. In Mississippi, he is licensed as a Professional Engineer. Like many in #engineering, Bert was good in math and science in high school and as they say, the rest is history. We like Bert's path to licensure as it brings focus to the fact that we need to attract students in the K-12 area when their interest in STEM courses, like math and science, are first peaked. Learn more about Bert and why professional licensure is important to him below: Q1. Why did you choose engineering? "I chose civil engineering because in school I was always good at math and physics, and the thought of being part of designing and building something that people would use every day like a roadway or bridge was very exciting to me. While I was in school, I started taking survey courses and interning on a survey crew over the summer, and I really enjoyed the experience, with the exception of the south Louisiana summer heat. At the time, the Louisiana Board of Professional Engineers and Land Surveyors had changed their rules to require surveyors to have a four-year degree. A minor was offered in Land Surveying, which was comprised of 30 hours, many of which were covered in my Civil Engineering curriculum so I decided to pursue the minor as well." Q2. How long have you been licensed in the State of Mississippi and do you also hold other state licenses? "I am a newly licensed professional engineer (P.E.) here in Mississippi, just having been licensed in 2024. I have been a licensed P.E. in Louisiana since 2004. I also hold professional licenses in Texas, Alabama, Georgia, Kentucky and Tennessee. I have been a licensed Professional Land Surveyor in Louisiana since 2010 and a Professional Transportation Operations Engineer since 2009." Q 3. What advice would you give to your younger self (HS grad, college grad, etc.)? "Civil Engineering is such a broad field. Make sure you get a good feel off all the aspects of the field before you settle down in a portion of it that you enjoy the most, and once you do, learn as much of it as possible and become an expert in that aspect. Once you do that, be open to helping the next generations to become experts as well." Q4. What would you say to young people, who might be interested in STEM careers such as engineering or surveying? "If you are enjoying STEM classes in school, I think you will enjoy a career in engineering or surveying." Q5. Tell us about a recent project you worked on that exemplifies why you love being an engineer and / surveyor? "We recently completed the design of a shared-use path and sidewalk through a busy interstate interchange corridor. Currently dozens of people are walking through the interchange on shoulders and medians to connect to places of business, residences and public transit and there are no safe paths through the interchange. Our designs created this safe path through the interchange along with ADA-compliant handicapped ramps, traffic signal modifications for pedestrian signals and timings, pedestrian lighting under the overpass, as well as other improvements. This project had a number of challenges that our team had to overcome and knowing that we were able to improve the quality of life for the community that we live in is a great feeling." Q6. Why is professional licensure important to you? "Professional licensure is important to me because it is a symbol of trust from the state board and my peers that I can be trusted to perform designs to improve our communities and mentor future generations on the standards of the engineering practice." October 2024 Engineer Spotlight: Dylan Wade, PE The Mississippi Board of Licensure for Professional Engineers and Surveyors would like to shine a spotlight on newly licensed Professional Engineer Dylan Wade. Dylan is a graduate of the Bagley College of Engineering where he received a Bachelor of Science degree in mechanical engineering. Dylan is a fourth generation engineer having received his PE license in April 2024. We were inspired by Dylan's encouragement to young people interested in a STEM career. "Never give up and keep pushing forward!" Learn more about Dylan and why professional licensure is important to him below: Q1. Why did you choose engineering? "I have always looked at engineering as the “Family Business”. I am a fourth-generation professional engineer in the state of Mississippi with three of those generations having graduated from Mississippi State. I always wanted to have the opportunity to be able to work with my father ( Dr. John T. Wade) who is a licensed mechanical engineer as well as a licensed fire protection engineer. Being in the practice of professional engineering you don’t get to see generations of family being able to work together and learn from each other very often." Q2. How long have you been licensed in the State of Mississippi and do you also hold other state licenses? "I received my MS PE in mechanical engineering in April of 2024. I am registered in two other states and have applied to an additional 4 states. All in the Southern region of the US." Q 3. What advice would you give to your younger self (HS grad, college grad, etc.)? "To never give up and to keep pushing forward. Everyone is going to fail from time to time, but the only thing you can do is learn from your mistakes and keep working. Never become stagnant and continue to learn new things to become the best engineer you can." Q4. What would you say to young people, who might be interested in STEM careers such as engineering or surveying? "To learn how to study before going to college. I was one of those graduates who didn’t have to study or do homework in high school. Everything just came naturally to me with lecture-based classes. When I moved to college I struggled with knowing how to study effectively to retain the information and being able to see things from the perspective required to strive in the engineering field." Q5. Tell us about a recent project you worked on that exemplifies why you love being an engineer and / surveyor? "I have been working on a project recently that has required me to relearn HVAC and plumbing design from the way I had usually done things. This project is a place of worship that is working to obtain the Living Building Challenge (LBC). This is a particularly difficult project due to the requirements laid out to earn this credential. The HVAC design must be able to achieve maximum efficiency and resiliency while drawing power from the solar panel system we implemented. The plumbing design is a different animal all on its own. 105% of the water used on site had to be offset by the recycling of rainwater and gray water. All the water on sight had to be recycled without the use of any chemical and be used for flushing and irrigation with little to know water going back to the sewer. There is a one-year period of collecting data after the project has been built where it must be proven that the building is 100% self sufficient within the resource limits of the site." Q6. Why is professional licensure important to you? "Licensure is important to me because it shows that an engineer has worked diligently and continued to grow as a professional through continued learning and adaptation. " See the article in our September 2024 #PEPTalks newsletter, where his father talks about the four generation of engineers in the Wade family. August 2024 Engineer Spotlight: Sarah Berman, PE The Mississippi Board of Licensure for Professional Engineers and Surveyors would like to shine a spotlight on newly licensed Professional Engineer Sarah Berman. Sarah is a graduate of Louisiana State University where she received a Bachelor of Science degree in civil engineering. We were inspired by one of Sarah's responses to our survey questionnaire. In her advice to her younger self, Sarah extends "grace" in allowing mistakes and we find that very powerful and much needed as often times the best life lessons, the best lessons are born out of mistakes. Ask any #Engineer and we believe they will agree. We are encouraged by Sarah and her enthusiasm for the future of the #engineering profession. We believe that you will be to. Learn more about Sarah and why professional licensure is important to her below: Q1. Why did you choose engineering? "After starting my freshman year as a Biology major, I quickly realized that it was not for me. I had a good friend who was studying architecture and thought that Civil Engineering would be something that I would be interested in. She was 100% right and the rest as the saying goes, is history." Q2. How long have you been licensed in the State of Mississippi and do you also hold other state licenses? "I received my Mississippi Professional Engineering license in June of 2024. I was first licensed in Louisiana in 2019." Q 3. What advice would you give to your younger self (HS grad, college grad, etc.)? "I would tell myself to remember to roll with the punches. Making mistakes and stepping out of your comfort zone may be challenging in the moment, but both offer invaluable lessons and opportunities for personal growth." Q4. What would you say to young people, who might be interested in STEM careers such as engineering or surveying? "Pursuing a career in engineering or surveying today offers young people a real opportunity to create change and shape the future of this country. Soon, the United States is going to be facing some real challenges with regards to its aging infrastructure. The next generation of engineers and surveyors will be able to create the innovative solutions critical to ensuring safety, efficiency, and sustainability when these systems are brought up to future standards." Q5. Tell us about a recent project you worked on that exemplifies why you love being an engineer and / surveyor? "Geotechnical Engineering has a very fast pace of work with a high volume of projects, so it is hard to pick a single one . What I can say is that due to that fast pace and high volume, I can drive through town and point out all of the projects that I have had a hand in and easily see how I am personally making a difference in building my community." Q6. Why is professional licensure important to you? "Professional licensure is important because it establishes a standard of quality and integrity that I believe is essential in our industry. It not only opens doors to professional opportunities for the individual, but also enhances the reputation and success of their companies." July 2024 Engineer Spotlight: William Burns Morrison, PE, SI The Mississippi Board of Licensure for Professional Engineers and Surveyors would like to shine a spotlight on Professional Engineer William Burns Morrison. Burns is a graduate of Mississippi State University where he received a Bachelor of Science degree in Civil Engineering. He is a unique spotlight feature choice for us in that he is licensed as a Professional Engineer but he is also enrolled as a Surveyor Intern. We think this is simply wonderful and well, we want to encourage him to continue on his route to dual licensure as both a PE and Professional Surveyor. And like many that we have featured before, he is a legacy in that his father is also a licensed engineer. We also like the fact that he is a two for one. We get to recognize him for being both a PE and a SI. Learn more about Burns and why professional licensure is important to him below: Q1. Why did you choose engineering? " My dad is also a civil engineer. I remember riding around town checking the drainage during heavy rain events with him starting at the age of 5. It was one of my favorite activities and still is to this day. I never questioned what I wanted to do. I always wanted to be a civil engineer. " Q2. How long have you been licensed in the State of Mississippi and do you also hold other state licenses? " I have been a licensed professional engineer since April 2024. I have applied to be licensed in Louisiana and hope to get licensed in Texas, Tennessee, and Arkansas. I will apply for my professional surveyor license in April of 2027. " Q 3. What advice would you give to your younger self (HS grad, college grad, etc.)? 1) I started working on the survey crew at the age of 16. That experience has proved to be invaluable. I can not recommend hopping on a survey crew or a construction crew for a few summers in HS and college enough. It helped me tremendously in college with concepts like grading, staking, and drainage. 2) Learn how to read complex construction drawings. There are a ton of videos on YouTube teaching people to learn how to read complex construction drawings. Doing this will set you above your peers coming out of HS or college. Q4. What would you say to young people, who might be interested in STEM careers such as engineering or surveying? " Young people are always on the cutting edge of technology. Use this knowledge to help better the firms you go to work for. " Q5. Tell us about a recent project you worked on that exemplifies why you love being an engineer and / surveyor? " We just completed the final site punch and as-built ALTA on the Pearl Apartments on Highway 80 in Jackson. It turned an abandoned hotel into senior living apartments equipped with an onsite healthcare clinic. We provided civil design and survey services for this project. It was a blast revitalizing this site. " Q6. Why is professional licensure important to you? " It is important to hold people accountable for the work they do. Nothing is more important than people’s health, safety, and welfare. Being a PE will allow me to offer professional services to the people and communities around me. " March 2024 Engineer Spotlight: Amanda Tritinger, PE The Mississippi Board of Licensure for Professional Engineers and Surveyors would like to shine a spotlight on Professional Engineer Amana Sue Tritinger. Amanda is graduate of the University of Central Florida where she received her Bachelor of Science degree in Environmental Engineering. She also holds a Master of Science Degree in Civil Engineering at the University of North Florida, and a Doctorate of Philosophy Degree in Coastal and Oceanographic Engineering at the University of Florida, respectively. We chose Amanda because her love and passion for #engineerng leaps off of the page in her words and she highlights several important factors that contribute to success in the engineering profession. T hose factors include the importance of a role model or mentor and encouragement to follow your passion even if it leads you in many directions. Amanda currently serves as the Research Hydraulic Engineer and Deputy Program Manager for the Engineering With Nature Program at the US Army Corps of Engineers in Vicksburg, Mississippi. "I’ve been licensed in the State of Mississippi since 2015 and I hold licensees in the State of Ohio (2014) and West Virginia (2013)." Q3. What advice would you give to your younger self (HS grad, college grad, etc)? "Be brave and smart in choosing a career which you will love and enjoy." Q4. What would you say to young people, who might be interested in STEM careers such as engineering or surveying? "Be passionate about your career because that is part of your life. "The professional licensure is important not just because it authorizes an engineer to provide professional services to the public, but also demonstrates an engineer’s adherence to a higher level of standards. It also indicates an engineer’s commitment to ethical practice with the health and safety of the public foremost in your consideration." October 2020 Engineer Spotlight: Matthew Hosey, P.E. The Mississippi Board of Licensure for Professional Engineers and Surveyors would like to shine a light on Matthew Hosey. Matthew received a Bachelor of Science degree in Civil Engineering from the University of Mississippi. Currently, he serves as a Project Manager with the Jackson County Board of Supervisors. We like Matthews encouragement to his high school self. "Study more! Its ok to be a nerd." More from our conversation with Matthew below: Q1. Why did you choose engineering or surveying? "I really liked maps and wanted to go into Cartography at first, but then decided Civil Engineering would be better because I would still get to create and read maps as well as do a lot of other really interesting things too. Also, I had a good amount of time between High School and going to college, during which I worked in various Construction fields. After working in construction, I thought I could bring my hands-on experience to the design side of projects and improve the outcome of projects." Q2. How long have you been licensed in the State of Mississippi and do you also hold other state licenses? "I have been licensed in Mississippi for 3.5 years and I also hold a Louisiana license." Q3. What advice would you give to your younger self (HS grad, college grad, etc)? "Stop trying to be cool, and study more! It’s ok to be a nerd." Q4. What would you say to young people, who might be interested in STEM careers such as engineering or surveying? "Don’t let the complicated math scare you. Anyone can learn it if you take it piece by piece and don’t get overwhelmed. I had to take remedial math in Elementary School, but then excelled at it in High School and College. Go for it and be Passionate about your studies! And learn to be interested in all things." Q5. Why is professional licensure important to you? "I know this is repeating what others have said before me, but it is true, Licensure holds us accountable for our actions. We touch countless lives every day when the public uses what we’ve designed, and without accountability, the world would not be as safe. Licensure is our lively hood, we must protect the public in order to protect our licensure and not let greed or power be our ruling factor." September 2020 Engineer Spotlight: L. Quinn Braboy, P.E. The Mississippi Board of Licensure for Professional Engineers and Surveyors would like to shine a light on L. Quinn Braboy. Quinn received a B achelor of Science degree in Civil and Environmental Engineering from Mississippi State University and a Master of Science degree in Civil and Environmental Engineering from Jackson State University. Currently, she serves as a Senior Civil Engineer with the City of Jackson. More on our conversation with Quinn below: Q1. Why did you choose engineering or surveying? "I have always been interested in science and math even at a very young age. I would build various things with my Legos and K’Nex toys, which fueled my interest in Civil engineering. In addition, I have an Uncle who is a licensed Civil Engineer that I looked up to and he has served as a great mentor over the years." Q2. How long have you been licensed in the State of Mississippi and do you also hold other state licenses? "I have been licensed in Mississippi since 2017 and also licensed in the state of Alabama." Q3. What advice would you give to your younger self (HS grad, college grad, etc)? "My advice to myself would be don’t dim my light for others to feel comfortable, do it scared and my silence serves no one." Q4. What would you say to young people, who might be interested in STEM careers such as engineering or surveying? "I would tell young people to ask others in STEM for advice or to shadow them, look for opportunities and if they aren't available create them, and don't be afraid to ask, most likely others are wondering the same things." Lastly, tell us why being a licensed Professional Engineer is important to you and the State of Mississippi. "It serves as a personal accomplishment and is important to maintain expertise in your field. In addition, it is great to network with other Professional engineers that you meet via different boards and organizations." August 2020 Engineer Spotlight: Jessica Headrick-Dilley, P.E. The Mississippi Board of Licensure for Professional Engineers and Surveyors would like to shine a light on Jessica Headrick-Dilley. Jessica has a Bachelors of Science degree in Civil Engineering and a Masters of Science degree in Environmental Engineering from the University of Mississippi. She currently serves as an Assistant State Planning Engineer with the Mississippi Department of Transportation. Check out some of our conversation with Jessica below: Q1. Why did you choose engineering? "I wanted a meaningful career in the field of math that would also give me diverse career options, but I also wanted a career where I could work to tangibly improve our environment (both built and non built)." Q2. How long have you been licensed in the State of Mississippi and do you also hold other state licenses? "I have been licensed in the State of Mississippi for 5 years." Q3. What advice would you give to your younger self (HS grad, college grad, etc)? "There is no better day than today - so be present in everything you do you may not get a redo later. - still working on this myself." Q4. What would you say to young people, particularly girls and children of color who might be interested in STEM careers such as engineering or surveying? "I never knew engineering was a “man’s” field until I was told so - I just knew I liked problem solving and math. With that said - the only person you need to prove anything too is yourself. The old saying “you can do anything you put your mind to” is so true - Everything requires hard work and studying but if it’s something you enjoy - it’s all worth it. Find out what you're passionate about and don’t be afraid to explore it." Lastly, tell us why being a licensed Professional Engineer is important to you and the State of Mississippi. "It is important because it holds engineers accountable for their work and design. A lot of what engineers do, particularly in the civil world, impacts the safety and welfare of the public. I wouldn't feel safe traveling with my family across bridges or a roadway in which there was no way to ensure they were designed to the correct (or any) code or standard."
